Title: Spectro-Thermometry of M dwarfs and their candidate planets: too hot, too cool, or just right?
Authors: Mann, A. W.; Gaidos, E.; Ansdell, M.
Table: Late-type Kepler Planet Host Parameters
================================================================================
Byte-by-byte Description of file: Stellar_params.txt
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   Bytes Format Units      Label  Explanations
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1-  4  I4    ---        KOI       Kepler Object of Interest Number
       6  A1    ---        f_KOI     Flag on KOI
   8- 15  F8    ---        KID       Kepler ID
  17- 20  I4    K          Teff      Effective temperature (1)
  26- 30  F5.3  Rsun       R*        Stellar radius
  32- 36  F5.3  Rsun       E_R*      Stellar radius error
  38- 42  F5.3  Msun       M*        Stellar mass
  44- 48  F5.3  Msun       E_M*      Stellar mass error
  50- 55  F6.4  Lsun       L*        Stellar luminosity
  57- 62  F6.4  Lsun       E_L*      Stellar luminosity error
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Note (1):
Error on Teff is assumed to be 58 K for all stars in the sample.
Note (2):
b = Consistent with Teff = 3820±90 K, R*=0.55±0.11$ and M* = 0.59±0.06 reported by Johnson et al. (2012).
c = Consistent with R*=0.54±0.05, M* = 0.57±0.05 reported by Pineda et al. (2013).
d = KOI 940 and KOI 2704 have Teff values outside our grid of calibration stars.
e = Kepler-32. Consistent with Teff=3793 +80/-74, R*=0.53±0.02, M*=0.54±0.02 reported by Swift et al. (2013).
f = Kepler-42. Consistent with Teff=3068±+174, R*=0.17±0.04, M*=0.13±0.05 reported by Muirhead et al. (2012b).
g = Kepler-61. Slightly warmer than, but consistent with Teff = 4017 +68/-150, R*=0.62 +0.02/-0.05, and M*=0.635±0.037 reported by Ballard et al. (2013).
h = KOI 2704 has a Teff cooler than our grid of calibration stars. We conservatively assign upper limits to this star based on the calibration star with the best matched temperature (GJ 699).
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
